Chapter 43

◎Combined Chapters◎

The ongoing disputes between Elder Madame Xu and her daughter-in-law, Madame Ji, did not dampen the enthusiasm with which Madame Ji and the entire Zheng family welcomed the Prince of Huaiyin and Huiyin. Even though Prince Wei had previously defeated the imperial army and Lü Wei and He Guoguo had taken control of Qingzhou, it did not change Zheng Fang's high regard for Li Cheng.

In his view, when Li Cheng led his troops to capture Xuzhou years ago, he had managed to hold onto it firmly, and the people of Xuzhou were very supportive of him. On the other hand, Xie Jiuyi, who had taken Qingzhou, was driven out. It was clear that if Li Cheng had been the one to take Qingzhou, the Crown Prince would not have been able to seize it.

Zheng Fang was now glad he hadn't gotten involved in Li Heng's affairs. Li Heng was still under Lü Wei's control, and even his favorite concubine had been executed. He was nothing more than a puppet. No matter how much he wanted to fight, his daughter wasn't capable of helping him. There was nothing in her belly, so what could supporting Li Heng achieve?

For now, it was better to remain neutral, avoiding any losses while gathering strength for a future counterattack.

Seeing Madame Ji's red-rimmed eyes, Zheng Fang understood her emotions. He set aside his favorite concubine and came over to comfort her. "We'll see our daughter soon. The scouts just reported that they've reached Bailipo."

"Lord, I understand," Madame Ji said. Her gratitude towards Zheng Fang exceeded her love for him. After all, he had protected her and her children when they were vulnerable, and their current status was due to this man standing before her. This was why she tolerated Elder Madame Xu.

Zheng Fang saw that Madame Ji had calmed down and sighed in relief. "Don't be too sad. It wouldn't be good if the Prince of Huaiyin saw you like this."

"Yes, Mother said she isn't feeling well today, so she won't be coming. I'll send a table of food and wine to her later," Madame Ji said.

Zheng Fang knew why his mother was upset, but taking his daughter back from the palace was a poor decision. If the Crown Prince ascended the throne, their daughter might at least become a consort. If the Crown Prince failed, they could make other plans. Since the Crown Prince hadn't mistreated De Yin, there was no reason to bring her back.

But he didn't dare to confront his mother directly. After all, she was his own mother. He could only pretend not to know.

Both husband and wife had their own calculations. The only one who was truly happy was Zheng Wuheng. He was still anxious to ride out to meet them, but Madame Ji said, "You're about to get married. Don't be so reckless. Your brother has already gone to meet them. Don't mess up your hair."

Xin Shi added, "Yes, little uncle, it's very windy outside. It's better to wait here."

Zheng Wuheng clung to Madame Ji, restless. Seeing his son, Zheng Fang felt joy. He only had this one son, Zheng Wuheng, so he wasn't a strict father. Instead, he doted on his youngest son quite a bit.

Compared to the indulgent father, Madame Ji was very strict with her son. Zheng Wuheng was obedient, though sometimes he slacked off. Still, he trained hard and was proficient in martial arts and tactics.

After a while, the scout reported back, "Lord, Lady, our young miss and her husband have arrived at the gate."

Only then did Madame Ji go out with Zheng Fang to welcome them.

Huiyin hadn't expected both her parents to come out. This was Li Cheng's first time visiting his in-laws' home in Jizhou. Even though he was a prince, he still felt like an anxious son-in-law. But outwardly, he maintained a calm and composed demeanor.

Huiyin wasn't as restrained. As soon as she saw Zheng Fang and Madame Ji, she rushed forward. "Father, Mother," she called, and then greeted her sister-in-law Xin Shi with a "Sister-in-law."

Before she could continue her introduction, she saw Zheng Fang and his wife bowing to Li Cheng. As a prince, Li Cheng's status was higher than theirs.

After the formal greeting, Li Cheng smiled at Huiyin. "Just now, I performed the national ceremony. Now, let me perform the family ceremony. Your son-in-law pays his respects to you, Father-in-law and Mother-in-law."

In truth, Li Cheng was also observing the Zheng family. Zheng Fang was tall, about seven feet, as tall as him. Though he was no longer young, his nose was straight like a jade pillar, and his mouth was red like cinnabar, making him very handsome. Dressed in a brocade robe with both civil and military sleeves, he looked dignified yet elegant, completely different from the Zheng Fang Li Cheng had imagined.

Looking at his mother-in-law, Madame Ji, like Huiyin, she was tall and strong, even slimmer, appearing capable and sharp.

Li Cheng also noticed that Zheng Fang and his wife were observing him. Madame Ji was particularly emotional. In her heart, her daughter was the best in the world, and there weren't many who could match her. In this chaotic world, a man's handsomeness didn't matter much. What was important was whether he could protect her.

Seeing this son-in-law, Li Cheng, dressed in a black python robe with golden clouds embroidered on the cuffs and a reddish-orange belt with inlaid beautiful jade, his black hair tied up with a hollow-carved gold crown, he looked both godly and unapproachable. The more Madame Ji looked, the happier she became. Her son-in-law not only doted on her daughter but also looked extraordinarily handsome and strong, not just a pretty face. The smile on her face deepened.

Looking at her daughter, who had been a young girl when she married, she was now a woman. Her bright forehead was exposed, and her hair was styled in a lily bun, making her look even more like a peach blossom with autumn water eyes. After such a long journey, she wasn't haggard at all but instead looked radiant. Madame Ji felt reassured.

"Prince, we have prepared a feast for you and the princess. Please sit and join us for a family reunion meal," Madame Ji said with a smile.

Li Cheng, of course, was humble. "Everything is at the discretion of the in-laws."

Zheng Wuheng was eager and impatient, wanting to talk to his sister and brother-in-law, but also looking at his brother holding his little nephew. He wished he had eight eyes to take everything in. Pei Shuo handed the baby to Zheng Fang, who weighed him in his hands. "This child is so well-proportioned. He must be over a year old."

Walking ahead, Huiyin turned around and smiled. "Father, what are you saying? Our Jing'er isn't one year old yet. But he's really healthy. He's already twenty pounds at just four months old."

Seeing that Zheng Fang was holding the baby, Madame Ji hurried over, looking very worried. "My lord, you should give the baby to the wet nurse. A man's hands are too rough; we wouldn't want to injure the baby's skin."

Huiyin hadn't had a chance to talk to Madame Ji since returning, and seeing how Madame Ji's eyes never left Jing'er, she felt a little jealous.

Laughing and chatting, they entered the house. Madame Ji had Li Cheng and Huiyin sit at the head of the table, while she and her husband sat below them. Opposite them sat Pei Shuo, his wife, and Zheng Wuheng.

Once everyone was seated, they heard Li Cheng talk about the journey. "We disguised ourselves when we came from Qingzhou to avoid unnecessary trouble. The adults could handle it, but Jing'er had diarrhea for a few days before he got better."

Huiyin felt that Li Cheng wasn't giving himself enough credit, so she added, "Actually, it was all thanks to the prince's arrangements along the way. When Jing'er fell ill, he immediately arranged a house for Jing'er to recover. We even encountered bandits, but we escaped unharmed. If it weren't for me, neither he nor the child would have gone through all that."

"Don't say that. I should have come to visit my in-laws sooner," Li Cheng said, feeling a bit embarrassed. Although he had indeed returned to satisfy his wife's homesickness, he didn't want to discuss such personal matters in public.

Both Zheng Fang and Madame Ji could see Li Cheng's shyness, and they were quite pleased. Zheng Fang even said, "It's the greatest joy for the Zheng family that the prince has accompanied the princess back to her parents' home. My son was previously in Xuzhou under your care, and I'm deeply grateful, Your Highness."

"Please, father-in-law, it's what I should do," Li Cheng replied with a smile.

When they heard that the banquet was ready, Huiyin and Li Cheng joined the others in the dining hall for the meal. Huiyin felt like she was back in her element, having not eaten home-cooked food for so long. Madame Ji helped her daughter by putting food on her plate. "This is your favorite fried shrimp. Have more."

"Mother, I will," Huiyin replied.

When she was at home in Jizhou, Huiyin rarely ate fried food. It wasn't that she didn't like it, but it was easy to get heaty, and as a young lady, she had to be mindful of her appearance.

Madame Ji loved watching her daughter eat and immediately served her another bowl of noodle soup. Meanwhile, Zheng Fang also spoke up, "Why serve this noodle soup? It's not appropriate for the Princess to eat this."

"Father, I like these. And is there any steamed cabbage rolls? I've been craving that dish," Huiyin said coquettishly.

"Bring that dish immediately," Zheng Fang urged the servants.

Parents show their love through endless feeding, especially Madame Ji and Zheng Fang. With Huiyin away from home, they felt as if they had lost their backbone.

Normally, such a grand banquet would be very formal, with the rule of "no talking while eating," and the Zheng family had always been like that. But seeing Huiyin so happy, Zheng Fang, who wasn't from a noble family, relaxed. He even used a small knife to cut roasted lamb and beef for Li Cheng and Huiyin.

Huiyin was worried that Li Cheng might think they were too informal, so she whispered, "My parents haven't seen me in a long time, so they're like this. It's not because they're treating you like an outsider."

"I understand. You don't need to explain," Li Cheng replied. He didn't find anything wrong with it and could see that his wife was very pampered at home.

"Are any of the dishes not to your taste? I'll talk to my mother. We have a chef who can cook southern dishes. We'll eat together then," Huiyin said with a smile.

Li Cheng nodded inwardly.

Pei Shuo had also been observing his younger sister and brother-in-law. Seeing the two whispering, it was clear they were very intimate in private. This young prince seemed far more genuine than the Crown Prince. He truly treated his sister well, traveling all this way to accompany her back for the visit, taking care of her the entire time, and having no concubines or secondary wives—even I would find that hard to do.

"Your Highness, I'd like to propose a toast to you. Our northern wine is strong. If you can't handle it, you can switch to the jade dew wine," Pei Shuo raised his cup.

Li Cheng laughed heartily. "Why not? I've been wanting to try this 'burning knife' wine."

The two of them, being of similar age, quickly became like brothers over drinks. Even Zheng Wuheng liked to join them, but Madame Ji wouldn't let him drink too much.

After the banquet, Li Cheng and Huiyin returned to freshen up. They also checked out the courtyard where they were now staying. It was a small, well-prepared courtyard by their family, very spacious. The front of the courtyard was filled with all kinds of flowers. Two cranes were drinking water, and a peacock was displaying its feathers. Not to mention the exquisite furniture inside, everything was of the highest quality.

Huiyin supported Li Cheng's arm as they sat down. "You drank so much; aren't you afraid it'll burn your heart? Now that you've bathed, you should rest properly. You've been exhausted from this journey; you need to take a break."

She had planned to have a private chat with her mother. When she was still at her parents' home, the two of them had endless things to talk about. Now that they were far apart and sending letters was inconvenient, she definitely needed to go.

But Li Cheng held her hand and said, "Can you stay and sleep with me?"

"I'll be back soon. I haven't had a private conversation with my mother since I came back. I have to go," Huiyin replied with a smile. Li Cheng seemed a little reluctant, but Huiyin understood. Since traveling from Jiangnan to Jizhou, the couple had been inseparable, spending every moment together. Now that they were separated, even if just for a short while, they both felt a little unaccustomed to it.

In our own home, Huiyin naturally wanted to spend time with her family. She said, "Tomorrow, we'll go to Brother's house for a meal, and Father will take you to inspect the border. There are many things to do, so go to sleep."

She covered Li Cheng's eyes with her hand, and he felt a warm sensation, which lulled him to sleep instantly.

Madame Ji hadn't slept either. Seeing her daughter come over, she patted the empty space on the bed. Huiyin quickly took off her shoes and climbed onto the bed, nestling together with her mother like they used to.

"Has the prince gone to sleep?" Madame Ji asked. Being a wife was different from being a daughter. As a daughter, one could be more carefree, but as a wife, one had to take care of one's husband first.

Huiyin nodded. "He's already asleep and didn't want me to leave. We're usually apart, so it's been hard to be together these days, which is why he was reluctant to let me go."

Hearing this, Madame Ji reminisced about her own wedding days with Pei Ye. He knew she loved the beef buns from the street corner, so he, a young master from a prominent family, queued up to buy them for her. He was anxious when she gave birth to Shuo'er, but that didn't stop him from caring for other women later.

However, she didn't want to mention this in front of her daughter. The early years of marriage were the happiest, and if she said something that caused misunderstanding between her daughter and son-in-law, what good would it do? Besides, even if Pei Ye was like that, there were still good men in the world.

Thus, Madame Ji teased, "He couldn't bear to part with you, which shows how strong your relationship is."

"Let's not talk about us. How are you, Mother? I heard my younger brother is getting married?" Huiyin asked in rapid succession.

Madame Ji smiled and said, "Hold on, let me answer one by one. I'm doing well, but your sister has been causing a fuss about wanting to come home. Your grandmother wants your father to fetch her, but both your father and I don't want to. Even the Crown Princess can't visit her parents' home freely, let alone a secondary consort like a Liangdi."

Huiyin agreed, "That's true. In my previous life, after becoming a Liangdi, I was mostly summoned by my family. Even as Empress Dowager, I couldn't casually return to my parents' home."

So, she was a bit speechless, "How could Grandmother make such an unreasonable request? Why is she suddenly so insistent on coming home?" In her previous life, after Li Cheng passed away, her sister didn't make a fuss about going home, but now she was.

Madame Ji sighed, "It's because a concubine in the Eastern Palace was beaten to death by Lü Wei after she became pregnant, and even her brother was implicated. Your sister witnessed her death and was frightened, thinking the Eastern Palace was a dangerous place. She chose to marry into it, and it's not like a regular family where she can just come back."

Madame Ji thought that if it were her own daughter, she would have done everything to protect her, but Huiyin wasn't her daughter. Zheng Fang turned a blind eye, so how could she interfere in such matters?

"A concubine beaten to death by Lü Wei? Was she from the Dong family? I think I heard about her from Tong Niangzi before." Huiyin was surprised that such a thing had happened, which didn't occur in her previous life.

Madame Ji nodded, "She was a concubine named Dong, originally a palace maid and one of Empress He's attendants. The Crown Prince didn't favor her much, but she was fortunate to be pregnant with the Eastern Palace's child, only to meet such an end. Actually, what does this have to do with your sister? Your father is the Grand Commander of Jizhou and a marquis; how could Lü Wei dare to clash with him now?"

Huiyin thought that in her previous life, although her father eliminated Lü Wei, his situation didn't improve much, and he had to follow the Crown Prince, only to realize later that the Crown Prince wanted to betray him.

But this Huiyin went to great lengths to change her marriage, yet she was so timid and hadn't discovered that the Crown Prince was giving them contraceptive medicine.

If I were in her position, I would need to have a child to persuade Zheng Fang. Otherwise, what leverage did she have?

"Mother, the main reason we came back this time with the prince is to visit family, but we also need to go to the palace to celebrate the Emperor's birthday. Otherwise, as the prince, who oversees the navy, he can't easily leave his post." Huiyin explained their purpose.

Madame Ji asked in a low voice, "Your father already knows about that. We'll go to the palace together. But there's one thing, I heard you and Zheng Fang delayed your wedding by more than ten days? Does he have any other women?"

Huiyin shook her head, "I'm not sure about his past, but he told me he didn't. However, he was quite skilled on our first night, not like a novice."

"And after you married, how has he been with you?"

"Even if he's injured, we sleep together. You know what? His grandmother didn't treat me well and tried to punish me, refusing to let me manage the household. When he returned, he sold all his grandmother's people and gave the money to me to manage." Huiyin said with a hint of sweetness.

Madame Ji was about to say something more when Huiyin continued, "When I was giving birth to Jing'er, he stayed by my side in the delivery room, holding me from behind and comforting me. At that moment, I was deeply moved. No matter what happens in the future, at least he's truly good to me. He has no parents, and his grandmother is quite muddled, but he's very good to me."

"You're defending him before I even say anything!" Madame Ji instructed, "I know he's good to you, so don't worry. I can see he's a fine man. As a member of the royal family, he's truly remarkable. But as a woman, you mustn't completely rely on a man."

Huiyin smiled, "Don't worry, Mother, I have a sense of proportion."

Madame Ji touched her daughter's hair and couldn't help but say, "When you came back today, I almost didn't recognize you. You look so good, like a peach blossom. I knew your life must be going well, and most importantly, giving birth to Jing'er is the best thing."

Back then, Madame Ji could still remarry with Pei Shuo, and even if she couldn't, when her son grew up, she would have someone to rely on. In these uncertain times, even a strong woman without family support or a son would be vulnerable.

"How are you and Father?" Huiyin asked, concerned about Madame Ji.

Madame Ji smiled. "Your father comes to see me a few times a month. He still consults me on important matters. Even those concubines, even the difficult ones, don't dare to say anything in front of me. I'm not afraid of them."

Madame Ji had a fighting spirit. Her gratitude towards Zheng Fang outweighed her love, and she didn't have a strong sense of possession. As long as they didn't go too far, she wouldn't care. Moreover, some of those concubines were former singers or dancers, born into poor families. In these turbulent times, they were like duckweed, very good at reading the room. They knew clearly who was in charge in the household.

"That's good. In the future, your daughter will also support you," Huiyin smiled.

Madame Ji lowered her eyes. "There's also your grandmother. I know her well. She might think your sister wasn't worthy of her son-in-law. But let's not talk about this. Since you're back, we'll choose an auspicious day. When the time comes around for your brother's wedding, you'll be able to meet your future sister-in-law."

Huiyin naturally agreed but frowned. "Mother, why the rush? Brother is only eighteen."

"That's already considered late. In our family, with all the battles, once your brother is married, people will start treating him as an adult. Also, if anything unexpected happens, it's good to leave behind a descendant." Madame Ji, born in the military, was more open about life and death than ordinary people.

Huiyin naturally asked about her brother's fiancée. "I've only heard from Lady Tong that Miss Cui is known for her virtue and grace. I don't know the details."

When mentioning her future daughter-in-law, Madame Ji couldn't help but say, "She's pretty but not seductive. She doesn't have the same beauty as you and your brother. However, her personality is very gentle, with a natural aura of gentleness. Although she's the youngest daughter in her family, she doesn't act coquettishly or throw tantrums. She's broad-minded. Your brother, who can be rash and headstrong, was immediately smitten with her."

"So it was my brother who fell for her. That reassures me. By the way, Princess Wu's family is related to the Cui family. When the time comes, I can visit his uncle's house with the prince." Huiyin relaxed.

The mother and daughter chatted about family matters for a while. Huiyin yawned and prepared to go back. Since she was home, she could talk to her mother for a long time.

Madame Ji had someone bring a lantern to escort her. "It's pitch black outside. Be careful."

"Mother, please don't see me off. I'll be careful. Besides, it's not cold, and there's no snow. Don't worry." Huiyin insisted on preventing Madame Ji from seeing her off.

As she left her mother's main room, she felt the moon was bright and the stars sparse. She was a bit emotional. In this lifetime, her sister was so timid. She couldn't help but wonder how Li Heng would cope with such a timid sister.

Just as she was thinking, she walked out of the courtyard and saw someone standing there with a lantern. The lantern light cast a glow on his blue brocade sleeve, and when she looked up at his jade-like face, his eyes, which had been vacant, suddenly filled with joy. In the dim light, Huiyin could see a warm, golden light in his eyes.

"Husband, why are you here?" Huiyin had assumed he was already asleep.

She wondered if he had come to confess something, or perhaps it was for her safety, or even out of reluctance to part.

To her surprise, Li Heng looked puzzled. "I wasn’t thinking. I just found myself walking here."

Huiyin laughed. "You have a sharp face but a slow heart. Couldn't you just say you missed me?"

title: Chapter 44
content:
Chapter 44

◎Combined Two Chapters◎

Huiyin was awakened by the chirping of birds and the voices of children. She hadn’t expected it to be broad daylight by then. When she sat up, she was momentarily disoriented, unsure of her surroundings.

Fugui and Qiufeng were sitting not far away, dividing threads on stools. When they heard the noise, they hurried over.

“What time is it now?” Huiyin asked, stifling a yawn. She leaned on a pillow, finally having slept soundly.

Fugui replied, “It’s almost noon, Lady Huiyin. Marquis Zheng Fang has taken the Little Prince to inspect the troops. He said he won’t be back for lunch and asked you to dine with the Lady of the Marquisate.”

Huiyin nodded. Her father had been able to hold on until now entirely due to his old foundations, which was also why both of his daughters were hedging their bets. Especially in recent years, her father had indulged in sensual pleasures and was no longer the man he used to be. Her brother, after all, bore the Pei family name and wasn’t being raised as a potential heir, and her younger brother was too young. The family was in a difficult transitional period.

For instance, in Prince Wei’s army, they used a new type of trebuchet. During a recent skirmish with bandits, when the bandits shot arrows down, they were all destroyed by the trebuchets. Li Cheng, being young and eager to learn, likely made the army under Prince Wei far more formidable than their own.

But she couldn’t express these concerns openly. After washing and dressing, she went to speak with Madame Ji. Madame Ji said, “Now that you are a princess, it’s we who should pay our respects to you. How could you come to us?”

“Mother, we’re all at home. Why worry about such formalities? Besides, I slept in until late morning. I’m already afraid of what people might say.” Huiyin leaned on Madame Ji’s shoulder and acted spoiled.

Madame Ji smiled and said, “You traveled a long way back. It’s only right that you sleep in longer. What’s the big deal? Who would dare say anything?”

The mother and daughter exchanged a knowing smile, seemingly deliberately forgetting about Elder Madame Xu. She claimed to be ill, and Huiyin had sent some tonics over, but no one really cared about her.

Feelings between people develop over time. Elder Madame Xu and Huiyin had little emotional connection, so there wasn’t much of a grandmother-granddaughter bond. Similarly, Grand Dowager Wu had some affection for Li Cheng after the death of his parents, but her indulgence of her greedy servants and her mistreatment of herself, driven purely by self-interest, had greatly disappointed Li Cheng.

As the mother and daughter sat down for lunch, Madame Ji said, “Your father seems to like your husband quite a bit. They discuss history and his past heroic deeds together, but your father also seems a bit insecure.”

It wasn’t that Zheng Fang was insecure; he was just getting old and felt incapable, yet he still had to hold on.

“Mother, my husband is considered both wise and brave in Prince Wei’s army. He’s intelligent and lives and eats with the soldiers, earning their respect. In the future, if father or my brothers encounter any difficulties, don’t hesitate to trouble us.” Huiyin, of course, wouldn’t immediately suggest anything about serving someone.

Even after she became Empress in her previous life, the threat of Wei Duo still existed, and her father would still be afraid. Her position as Empress Dowager was actually precarious.

Now, with a calm heart, Huiyin naturally hoped her family could become self-reliant. But if that failed, they would need to quickly find a backer. Lü Wei and He Guoguo weren’t easy to deal with. Li Cheng was capable. If he makes a firm decision, the Zheng family could still survive.

Madame Ji was very pleased to hear her daughter’s thoughts. “You’re always the one who thinks of us. Unlike your elder sister, who makes your father want to kill Lü Wei one day and asks him to bring her back the next. She’s not capable herself but is good at ordering others around.”

“As a daughter, one should naturally share the worries of one’s parents. By the way, I heard that Lü Wei has been throwing his weight around recently and that He Guoguo is quite dissatisfied. Is that true?” Huiyin sipped her tea and asked.

Madame Ji smiled faintly. “It’s a well-known fact. Besides, Dong Yuniang was a person given to the Crown Prince by Empress He. As the saying goes, ‘Even if you don’t respect the monk, you should respect the Buddha.’ Yet Lü Wei dares to act this way. The Crown Prince used to favor the Crown Princess, but recently, he seems to have grown quite cold towards her. He can only rebel in these small ways.”

Huiyin thought it made sense, but she said, “Has my elder sister, who is by the Crown Prince’s side, found out anything? What about the He family’s arrangements and the Crown Prince?”

“She’s only concerned with gaining favor and affection. How could she think about anything beyond her own desires? Yet she still expects us to prioritize her?” Madame Ji was at a loss for words.

Xu Shi was still alive, living in her temple and harboring hopes of rising again through her daughter, though she wasn’t foolish enough to think it would be easy.

After the meal, it was heard that Xin Shi had come over. She had specifically invited Huiyin to listen to a play. Huiyin certainly wouldn’t refuse her sister-in-law, especially since Xin Shi had been busy the day before. The two sisters-in-law had gotten along well enough.

When Pei Shuo married, Madame Ji had given him a residence in Tongling Ward. Last year, Xin Shi had connected the neighboring house, making it even larger. Xin Shi had specially built a theater there and was explaining as she spoke.

“We’ve invited the Four Joy Troupe. Princess, it’s been two years since you’ve been in Jizhou. Why not listen to some local plays from Jizhou? The movements are quite wonderful.” Xin Shi introduced.

Huiyin nodded slightly.

Today, she was undoubtedly the center of attention. Xin Shi had invited guests from her parents' home and local gentry families. Among them was a young woman who, for a moment, reminded Huiyin of Yin Liyi.

Xin Shi introduced her, “This Madam Zhang is from the Cui family of Boling.”

The local aristocratic families of Zhang and Cui in Hebei were quite renowned, and the two often intermarried. Although Huiyin didn’t recognize this Madam Zhang, she assumed that anyone invited by Madam Xin would certainly be of high standing.

Madam Zhang hurriedly came forward to pay her respects. Huiyin smiled and gently waved her off: “Madam, there’s no need for such formality.”

In truth, Huiyin wasn’t particularly adept at socializing. Deyin was more skilled at socializing; she knew how to make friends quickly, what to wear and say for different occasions, and even how to play games. Huiyin had once admired Deyin greatly for this, but now she could handle social situations with ease. She had come to understand that without the backing of real power, all these so-called social skills meant nothing.

If you have influence, even a casual remark can draw admiration.

Now, even though she admitted she didn’t understand opera, everyone was eager to explain it to her, treating it as an honor to do so.

Next to her, Madam Xin’s mother, Elder Madam Xin, spoke to Madam Ji: “Now that the princess has returned to her parents' home, I wonder if we might have the honor of hosting Her Highness.”

Madam Ji explained: “In a few days, they will head to the capital for the emperor’s birthday celebrations, so they won’t be staying long. I also mentioned that the relatives at home are all waiting for you to return so we can have a lively gathering, but the prince and princess are busy; we can’t delay their important affairs, can we?”

Madam Xin immediately understood. Neither side genuinely wanted this, but both had found a way to give the other a graceful exit.

The table was filled with the pastries, teas, and wines that Huiyin loved when she was still in the boudoir. Though she didn’t like drinking alcohol, she particularly enjoyed iced grape beverages or wine. As soon as she finished a cup, the servants behind her would refill it. Huiyin drank half a cup more, and when the opera performance was nearly done, she went to see her nephew, Guge. The child resembled his mother, Xin Shi, but was noticeably thinner, which was more typical for a child his age.

Madam Ji looked at her grandson and sighed: “Look how thin Guge is. He had diarrhea for many days and even hit his head. I don’t know how your sister-in-law takes care of him.”

“Mother, no mother would deliberately harm her own child. It’s normal for children to have bumps and bruises. Even Jinger traveled so far with me, and I couldn’t bear to see him like that.” Huiyin gently squeezed her nephew’s small hand.

She had brought a gift for her nephew, including writing supplies, a longevity lock, gold and silver bracelets, and a box of intricate toys like clay whistles, kites, nine-linked rings, and ceramic rattles. She even brought two carts of exquisite soft silk clothes for the child.

When Xin Shi came in and saw her mother-in-law holding the child and her sister-in-law looking at Guge with affection, she felt warmth in her heart. Xin Shi had been thinking long-term. After all, this region of Jizhou would eventually belong to Zheng Wuheng, with Pei Shuo currently holding it on his behalf. In the future, the elder brother would have to defer to the younger. Her husband might not accept this easily.

In this vast world, with various powers vying for control, one had to choose between joining the crown prince, Prince of Wei, Wei Duo, He Guoguo, or even warlords like Lü Wei. Xin Shi thought that since her sister-in-law had married the Prince of Huaiyin and seemed to be greatly favored, perhaps her husband could also pledge himself to the Prince of Huaiyin. The prince had spoken confidently at the banquet yesterday and showed great courage, leading two thousand soldiers without fear even when passing through Qingzhou. Such bravery wasn’t something ordinary people possessed.

With such a heroic brother-in-law and her sister-in-law thriving in the ancestral lands of her maternal family, Xin Shi thought it wouldn’t be impossible for her husband to pledge allegiance to the Prince of Huaiyin. This way, Madam Ji wouldn’t be too upset either.

So, Xin Shi became even more enthusiastic toward Huiyin. Huiyin, of course, understood her thoughts. She was waiting until Li Cheng truly took power, at which point she could formally extend an invitation.

But for now, being outnumbered and without real power, she couldn’t make guarantees to her natal family. She had to proceed slowly; otherwise, the variables would be too great, and things could backfire.

Thus, Huiyin brought up a light topic: “By the way, Sister-in-law, is Madam Zhang from the same branch of the Cui family as my younger brother’s fiancée?”

Xin Shi smiled: “They both seem to come from the main branch of the Qinghe Cui family, but Madam Zhang is from a concubine’s line. The woman my younger brother is marrying is from the legitimate wife.”

Madam Ji added with a slight smile: “You may not know this, but Madam Cui comes from the prestigious Longxi Li family, which shares the same surname as the imperial family, making her lineage highly distinguished.”

“To me, whether someone is from the main line or a secondary line isn’t as important as having a good heart.” Huiyin, who once cared about these things, now believed that having a righteous heart was more important than anything else.

That said, there were still subtle differences in status. For example, Huiyin and Deyin didn’t have a large status gap, but Huiyin had brothers, while Deyin didn’t, which made Deyin’s words carry less weight. If one was born to the main wife and had a brother who might be the future head of the family, that person’s influence would be different.

After returning from her elder brother’s home, Jinger was clamoring for his mother. Huiyin spent the entire afternoon playing with her son. It was only when the sky began to darken that Li Cheng returned.

Li Cheng strode in, one corner of his clothes tucked into his waistband, looking even more refreshed.

Huiyin stood up, wrung a towel, and handed it to him: “Why are you back so late? Where did you all go today?”

Li Cheng wiped his face and couldn’t help but smile: “I went to inspect the Jizhou army. I even arranged for my soldiers to have a friendly match with the Jizhou army. Your father agreed to it.”

“That’s wonderful. My father wishes for someone like you to be by his side, but he has a weakness: his resolve isn’t firm, and he’s easily swayed by others. As his son-in-law, with both literary and martial abilities, don’t be too formal.” Huiyin hoped they could maintain a good relationship.

Speaking of Zheng Fang, he wasn’t inherently evil. People criticized him for killing Lu Ji because they saw him as impulsive and self-serving. But in this complex world, who can truly be relied upon for loyalty?

Even Prince of Wei had taken a significant amount of Prince of Wu's territory, and Li Cheng didn't dare to say anything.

Before coming to Huiyin's parents' home, Li Cheng had assumed the Zheng family would be very defensive toward him, but it turned out they were quite sincere. He cleared his throat lightly, "They didn't treat me as an outsider."

Huiyin nodded. "That's good. I just asked my mother, and she said my younger brother is preparing to get married in half a month. We can attend both the Emperor's birthday celebration and my brother's wedding, and then return."

Huiyin wondered if this timeline might be a bit too long, and wasn't sure if Li Cheng would agree.

Unexpectedly, Li Cheng readily agreed. "That's fine."

"But is everything alright in Xuzhou?" Huiyin asked.

Li Cheng was indeed worried, but if he eliminated Lü Wei now, his prestige would rise, and no one would be able to replace him. This was his plan, and he sensed his father-in-law agreed.

So, he reassured Huiyin, "Everything's fine. Don't worry, enjoy the time with your parents."

Huiyin nodded.

Elder Madame Ji was full of vitality. In the evening, they had planned for a simple meal, but she prepared a small banquet instead. Huiyin and Li Cheng attended, and with the music, it became a joyous gathering.

However, to Elder Madame Xu, this felt like mockery. Nanny Luo couldn't help but say, "Actually, Second Miss also sent tonic. Why don't you go out and meet them? Would they dare to disrespect you?"

Elder Madame Xu glanced out the window. "I heard the Prince of Huaiyin treats Second Miss very well?"

"Yes, he came to pick her up in the evening and brought gifts for everyone in the household. Even the servants received fine fabrics from Jiangnan, let alone the others." Nanny Luo also felt regretful. If the eldest miss had married the Prince of Huaiyin, she would likely have children by now.

Elder Madame Xu decided to stop pretending to be sick. She wanted to see if this Prince of Huaiyin was genuinely good to her granddaughter.

The next day, Huiyin and her husband met Nanny Luo, who conveyed that Elder Madame Xu's health had greatly improved and that she wished to see her great-grandson.

Huiyin smiled. "I actually wanted to pay respects to grandmother on the day we returned, but I was afraid of disturbing her due to her illness. Now that she has recovered, I will go with the prince to pay our respects."

As soon as she finished speaking, Nanny Nan looked troubled. "Your Highness, why would you and the prince go in person?"

"She's our family grandmother; why put on airs?" Huiyin shook her head.

Nanny Luo was startled and realized that both she and Elder Madame Xu had forgotten. This wasn't just any married-off lady returning to her family; it was the prince and princess. There was a distinction between ruler and subject.

She quickly said, "Although the princess is approachable, our elder Madame Xu insists on observing propriety. She will come to see the young prince later."

Huiyin didn't refuse further. Once Nanny Luo left, Li Cheng was visibly annoyed.

No wonder Huiyin said Elder Madame Xu was difficult. Even during a princess's return to her family, there was still an air of superiority. He had to meet this elder Madame Xu properly.

Because of Nanny Luo's message, Elder Madame Xu realized she had breached etiquette. Though reluctant, she came over under the pretext of seeing Jing'er and certainly didn't want to perform the formal greeting. Huiyin didn't intend for her elder family member to kneel and quickly stepped forward to help Elder Madame Xu up. "Grandmother, there's no need for such a formal gesture. You are my elder; this is absolutely not allowed."

"Etiquette cannot be neglected, Princess is too kind." Elder Madame Xu had never liked Huiyin. She knew Huiyin's respect was just pretense. If she truly respected her, why put on airs?

Elder Madame Xu said in a seemingly affectionate tone, "I felt unwell when you returned, as I was concerned about passing my illness to you."

Li Cheng smiled. "It's a filial duty to pay morning and evening respects, but we rushed back, carrying the dust of the journey, and were also concerned about passing on any illness."

Elder Madame Xu couldn't help but notice Li Cheng. She had thought Crown Prince Li Heng was unparalleled in handsomeness, noble and elegant, and few could match his appearance. Unexpectedly, Li Cheng was also very handsome, with a dashing demeanor, clear brows, and sharp speech. Though raised in Jiangnan, he spoke Mandarin very well.

If De Yin had married the Prince of Huaiyin as planned, just look at this precious little one, so endearing!

Bringing her thoughts back, Elder Madame Xu began to reminisce. "I heard your maternal uncle's family is from the Cui family of Qinghe?"

Li Cheng smiled. "This prince's uncle is General Bo Ling Cui Xun."

Huiyin noticed that Li Cheng referred to himself as "this prince" when speaking to Elder Madame Xu, but when talking to his mother, Madame Ji, he called himself "your son-in-law." The difference was quite significant, but one couldn't fault him for maintaining his status as a prince.

"Oh, what a coincidence! Your younger brother is marrying the daughter of the main branch of the Canghe family. It's truly a case of kin marrying kin. I believe your uncle also had a daughter who married into the Zhang family," said Elder Madame Xu, trying to show off her knowledge of familial relations.

Li Cheng nodded. "After the passing of my father, the Prince, and my mother, the Princess, we haven't kept in touch due to the distance. I wasn't aware of the affairs in my uncle's household, but this time, I plan to visit him with the princess." In truth, after the death of the Prince and Princess of Wu, Li Cheng had written to his uncle, but Cui Xun always made excuses and was unwilling to truly support him, not even willing to make a trip. At that time, Li Cheng was isolated and had grown indifferent to this uncle.

These matters were not something he could discuss with outsiders, especially since after the conquest of Xuzhou, his uncle had written several times.

Recalling that his mother was raised by his uncle and aunt, Li Cheng couldn't bring himself to completely sever ties.

Elder Madame Xu, hearing this, circled back, "Just have some congratulatory gifts prepared and sent over."

These familial matters didn't make Elder Madame Xu seem like a major issue to Li Cheng. As long as they maintained a courteous facade, everything would be fine as long as she didn't act out. He would treat her with normal respect.

However, Elder Madame Xu couldn't hold back. She glanced at Huiyin and said with a smile, "This second granddaughter of mine has always been mischievous. If she offends you, Prince, please don't take it to heart. Just let me know."

"Please rest assured, Elder Madame Xu. The princess is gentle and virtuous. She is kind to me and the people of my fief, and she is well-loved," Li Cheng naturally spoke well of Huiyin. He wasn't foolish enough to think speaking ill of his wife would elevate him.

Elder Madame Xu smiled. "Yes, this granddaughter of mine has always been charming. There was a young gentleman who was so infatuated with her that he was willing to die for her. I told her parents that such a clever and lovely child shouldn't be married off hastily. Coincidentally, my natal family, the Xu family of Donghai, came to our Jizhou, which led to your perfect match."

Li Cheng had heard about this from Huiyin before. Apparently, there were those who called her a temptress, which was why Huiyin rarely socialized afterwards. She was admired by someone who, when she didn't reciprocate, vilified her.

If Li Cheng had only known about Elder Madame Xu through Huiyin's words, hearing her mention it now made him narrow his eyes. This old woman is overstepping. Despite my courtesy, she now speaks in a sarcastic manner.

Huiyin was also angry. As the saying goes, family shame should not be aired in public. While Elder Madame Xu had been distant and cold to them at home, she had never acted like this outside. Huiyin was worried that Elder Madame Xu might speak ill of her to Li Cheng, but to say such things in front of her, implying she was fickle, was clearly intentional, meant to undermine her in Li Cheng's eyes.

Nanny Luo, standing next to Elder Madame Xu, knew that the old lady was upset. Neither the Marquis nor his wife cared about the eldest daughter's well-being, and the second daughter's return with an air of nobility was clearly a challenge, deliberately making the elderly suffer.

If the Prince of Huaiyin could see through the second daughter's true nature, it would be a blow to Madame Ji.

Unexpectedly, Li Cheng, furious, smiled instead, "You are mistaken, Elder Madame Xu. This has nothing to do with the Xu family of Donghai. After much inquiry, this prince learned that the princess is the most beautiful woman in Jizhou and a paragon among women. Thus, I asked Uncle Wang of Wei to propose marriage for me. At that time, it was said that there were two young ladies in your family, but it was Huiyin that I favored and had always wished to marry. Thankfully, fortune smiled upon me, and my dream came true. I married the woman I had always desired."

Upon hearing this, Huiyin felt her heart swell with warmth, as if it had been filled with honey. She glanced at Elder Madame Xu, whose face turned pale with anger, and thought, "Now you've brought shame upon your beloved granddaughter!"

title: Chapter 45
content:
Chapter 45

◎Combined Double Chapters◎

Huiyin didn't know how Elder Madame Xu felt when she left, but she herself felt much better. Nevertheless, she still said to Li Cheng, "You shouldn't have brought up my elder sister. She's not having a smooth time as Liangdi in the Eastern Palace. My grandmother is already upset, and seeing how affectionate we are might make her say something unpleasant."

"That's no reason for her to speak poorly of you. Are you not also her granddaughter?" Li Cheng, who was inherently indifferent to familial affection, especially when family members failed to support each other and even disparaged Huiyin in front of him, believed that Elder Madame Xu was not a good grandmother.

Huiyin smiled and said, "Alright, I understand. You're always thinking of what's best for me. Let's not talk about this anymore. You mentioned visiting your uncle's house; I'll prepare the gifts. If it's feasible, we'll go."

Li Cheng nodded. "You draw up the list, and I'll check if anything needs to be added or removed."

"Sure." Huiyin didn't feel that Li Cheng was doubting her. When they handled matters as a couple, they were always open to each other's suggestions without any possessive attitudes.

Li Cheng was about to say something more when they heard the voices of Pei Shuo and Zheng Wuheng outside. Huiyin nudged him. "Go with them; it's important for you to socialize too."

For someone his age, Li Cheng was unusually mature. Constantly dealing with intrigue could wear a person down, so spending time outside would help him feel more refreshed.

Li Cheng smiled. "Alright, I'll go out and see what they want. If it's nothing important, I'll come back early."

Of course, he didn't come back early, which Huiyin had anticipated. So, she began drafting the list. Given how generous the Cui family had been in the past, they couldn't afford to give less this time.

It was nearly dusk when Li Cheng returned, looking quite pleased. Huiyin showed him the list she had prepared, to which Li Cheng had no objections. He flopped onto the bed, resting his head on his arms, and said to her, "The Emperor's birthday is coming up in a few days, so we need to leave for the Cui family soon and avoid any delays on the way."

"We can leave our son with my mother. Knowing she'll take care of him will give me peace of mind." Huiyin smiled.

Li Cheng clapped his hands and laughed. "That's perfect. Our son won't have to endure the journey with us. This is a good thing."

The two planned that the next day, they would first send a fast horse to inform the Cui family, and then they would follow after. The journey from Jizhou to the Cui family would take about a day and a half.

Huiyin had imagined Cui Xun to be a handsome man in his forties, similar to her mother-in-law, Lady Wu, who would be in her early forties if she were still alive. But Cui Xun was already in his sixties, with graying hair and sagging skin, though he remained well-preserved.

But she wouldn't ask if Lady Li was a second wife, as that would be impolite.

So, Huiyin simply sat down and exchanged some trivial remarks with Lady Li. "I got married a few years ago, but I didn't expect that our families would become even closer relatives."

She had initially thought it might be a different branch of the Cui family, but it turned out that Uncle Cui's daughter was marrying her younger brother.

Lady Li clearly doted on her daughter. "My daughter is of humble appearance, but it is her fortune to be favored by the Marquise. The engagement will take place soon, and it will be her honor that both the Prince of Huaiyin and the Princess will attend the ceremony. Would you like my daughter to prepare some tea for you?"

Huiyin readily agreed. "Why not? I'd like to meet her too."

Miss Cui, whose small name was Yuehuan, wore a white jade crown and light purple flowers in her hair, with a matching dress. She was graceful and elegant. Huiyin silently praised her and sipped the tea she offered.

She watched Miss Cui prepare the tea seven times, resulting in a pure white color and fine, even froth. Her technique was impressive.

Huiyin took another sip. "Yes, the taste is right, the aroma is clear and pleasant, and the color is beautiful. Excellent, excellent."

Lady Li and Miss Cui exchanged glances, both pleased.

Miss Cui, trying to socialize like the adults, said, "This tea is called Ling Tea. If you enjoy it, Princess, we can send some over for you."

"Sure, pack two bags for me. Any more, and I won't be able to finish it." Huiyin smiled.

Li Cheng dismounted quickly and approached as he saw the Cui family waiting at the gate.

But he was still a robust and imposing figure, befitting his former status as a general.

Madame Cui was also very happy and added, "When I married into the family, my younger sister-in-law was about to get married. Although we didn't spend much time together, we have been thinking of each other over the years while being separated by distance. When we heard the news of Princess Zheng's passing, my husband was so heartbroken that he couldn't make the journey to attend the funeral. This has been weighing on his mind, and he hasn't been able to forget it."

"Given his condition and the long journey, I’m sure my late mother-in-law wouldn’t have blamed him," Huiyin thought. If the relationship had truly been close, he would have gone no matter what. She had heard from Li Cheng that Princess Zheng had only one brother.

When she went back home, her brother met her three hundred miles from the capital.

Madame Cui felt relieved when Huiyin said this. She was wholeheartedly intent on making this marriage alliance successful. Zheng Wuheng, the son of the Marquis of Zhaojie, was young, the heir and only son. Moreover, Jizhou was under the jurisdiction of the Marquis of Zhaojie. This marriage would be beneficial for both her daughter and the Cui family.

At lunch, the Cui family had prepared fine wine, but Li Cheng ate a little and prepared to leave, saying he was getting ready to go to the capital. The Cui family didn’t try to keep him, but Huiyin said to Lady Cui, "In the future, we'll be relatives, so it will be easier to visit each other. We'll have more opportunities to meet."

After getting on the carriage, Huiyin furrowed her brow. Li Cheng, seeing this, asked in surprise, "What's wrong? Are you not satisfied with my cousin?"

"It's not that. I was just thinking that your uncle's age seems like he could be Lady Cui's father. Is she a second wife?" Huiyin was curious.

Li Cheng waved his hand. "Of course not. You don't know that in this dynasty, noble families must marry someone of equal status. My uncle lost his father young and raised his younger sister, who is my mother. My uncle is eighteen years older than my mother, and he essentially raised her. He had high aspirations and came from a prestigious family. It wasn't until he was in his thirties, when he received an official title, that he had the qualifications to marry into one of the five great surnames, the Li family of Longxi."

"I see. Since I'm not from a noble family, I wouldn't have known that," Huiyin realized.

Li Cheng added, "After marrying, my uncle and his wife had two sons and a daughter. My elder cousin was recruited by Wei Duo. It's truly a case of like father, like son."

Huiyin, resting her chin on her hand, found it strange. "If your uncle hadn't made it big, would he have remained without a woman? How would the household have been managed?"

"Even without a principal wife, there would be concubines," Li Cheng saw nothing strange about it.

After visiting Li Cheng's uncle, they returned first to the Marquis of Zhaojie's residence in Jizhou. The couple was most concerned about their son, and they were surprised to see Jing'er nestled in Madame Ji's arms.

Madame Ji smiled and said, "When you first left, he cried for half an hour. After that, he became very attached to me. He's been sleeping with me these past few days."

"It seems it's not the child who can't leave the adults, but us adults who can't leave the child," Huiyin tickled Jing'er, making him giggle.

The women were primarily focused on household affairs. On the surface, Li Cheng appeared to be out having fun with his brothers-in-law, but in reality, he and Zheng Fang were discussing the plan to eliminate Lü Wei with He Guoguo.

It took only a day to travel from Jizhou to the capital by carriage. The streets of the capital were already decorated with lanterns and streamers to celebrate the emperor's birthday.

This time, Madame Ji wouldn't be coming. She had already entered the palace many times and didn't want to deal with Empress He. She always said that Empress He was full of schemes. Thus, Madame Ji reported an old illness and stayed home to look after Jing'er. On the other hand, Elder Madame Xu, at her advanced age, still had to go. Everyone knew why, and it was understood.

In truth, entering the palace was no big deal for Huiyin, but for Li Cheng, it stirred new and strange thoughts.

Born in a vassal state and raised in the Jiangnan region, he was still a descendant of Emperor Taizong, with the blood of Emperor Taizong flowing through his veins. Seeing the frail emperor behind the curtains and Prime Minister Lü Wei standing beside him, Li Cheng thought that if he were the emperor, he would have executed such a rebellious figure. The moment this thought arose, he felt his ambition was too great.

"Your subject, Prince of Huaiyin, Li Cheng, along with Princess Zheng, offer birthday greetings to the emperor. We wish Your Majesty a long and prosperous life," Li Cheng and Huiyin bowed together.

Huiyin, slightly raising her eyes, saw the hall brightly lit as if it were daytime. Standing below the emperor was Crown Prince Li Heng, with Lü Wei on either side. Li Heng, with elegance and nobility, had a smile at the corner of his mouth. The shadows from the lamps covered half of his face, adding a touch of mystery.

To Huiyin, Li Heng now seemed like a stranger.

The emperor, coughing for a long time, seemed pleased as he said, "You are the son of the Prince of Wu's brother. You are, in fact, my close nephew. Come closer and let me take a look at you."

Li Cheng stood up, adjusted his clothes, and walked forward, appearing even more outstanding and imposing. Li Heng also seemed to notice his cousin, the Prince of Huaiyin, for the first time. He had heard that Li Cheng was in the capital to celebrate the emperor's birthday on behalf of the Prince of Wei and that he had been training the navy for the Prince of Wei, becoming famous in the Jiangnan region at a young age.

More importantly, he had married the second daughter of the Zheng family, while another had married the eldest daughter.

As Li Cheng ascended the steps, the light seemed to follow him. The rows of candles illuminated his path. Li Heng looked up, and Li Cheng stopped, smiling as he greeted him.

The emperor studied Li Cheng for a moment and smiled. "The Prince of Huaiyin is truly remarkable and handsome, worthy of being the son of the Prince of Wu. Since you've come from your fief to celebrate with me, I can't let you leave empty-handed."

The attendants by the emperor's side read a long list of rewards, and Li Cheng thanked him. But inwardly, he felt somewhat disappointed. He had thought the emperor might ask him about his usual activities or how things had been in the fief since his father's passing. It seemed he was merely a figure to display the emperor's harmony with his kin.

At this moment, Li Cheng had to maintain his perfect composure as the Prince of Huaiyin.

After Li Cheng came down from the stage, Huiyin sat down with him. Today, the emperor was celebrating in the three main halls, while royal family members like them were celebrating together with the emperor in Lijing Hall.

"You did great," Huiyin whispered to Li Cheng once she was seated, careful that no one around noticed.

Li Cheng felt a warmth in his heart. Everyone else was concerned about his status and whether he had received any rewards, but only Huiyin worried that he might be nervous and was concerned about him as a person.

The couple smiled at each other, but Deyin, sitting opposite, caught sight of Li Cheng unexpectedly. In her previous life, Li Cheng had never entered the capital, and the two had never even met. Yet now, they appeared to be a loving couple, which was increasingly disheartening for her.

If her grandmother had warned her about the relationship between Huiyin and Li Cheng earlier, she might have had time to prepare herself. After the crown prince sat down, he even whispered, "My father told me that the Prince of Huaiyin is accompanying his sister back to her family for a visit. You two haven't seen each other for a few years; you might want to go and have a chat with her."

No wonder—Li Cheng was accompanying his sister back for a family visit and also participating in the emperor's birthday celebration.

In her previous life, she and Li Cheng had rarely been together. Even when he returned to Jianye, it was just a fleeting glimpse, and they had no interaction. He had been very caring towards Yin Lijun, the daughter of a recorder, but even though he treated Yin Lijun well, he had never gone out of his way to do something like this for a woman.

"Is that so? I'm often in the Eastern Palace and know nothing about family matters. Fortunately, the crown prince informs me," Deyin said with a forced smile, pretending to be virtuous and magnanimous.

Li Heng also wanted to win over Li Cheng. Between him and the Prince of Wei, of course, he had the advantage. Once the emperor passed away, he would rightfully become the crown prince, while the Prince of Wei, stationed in a remote region under the title of royal family, could only dream of being legitimate.

But honestly, what he could offer Li Cheng right now was not as much as what the Prince of Wei could. However, if Li Cheng sided with him, together they could take over Jizhou, Qingzhou, and even Xuzhou.

So, he needed Deyin's help to act as an intermediary.

Deyin understood Li Heng's intentions. She looked at Huiyin across from her and was somewhat stunned. In her previous life, the crown prince doted more on her younger sister, who had a successful pregnancy and gave birth to a son, later becoming the empress dowager. In this life, Huiyin was also deeply loved by Li Cheng. She really wanted to know how her sister had managed to win Li Cheng's heart.

As an older sister, she shouldn't feel this jealous, but she didn't think she was inferior to Huiyin in any way.

Back in the day, she had a wide circle of friends, and her home was always bustling with wealthy and noble suitors, while her sister was more reserved and received far fewer proposals. It wasn't until later that Madame Ji, seeing that her sister was inferior in every way, started claiming that her daughter was the first beauty of Jizhou, spreading the word about her daughter's beauty.

How could their fortunes change so drastically after marriage? Ultimately, her sister's advantage was having a brother to support her. If she had a brother, how could she have fallen to such a state without anyone to help her?

This was innate and not because she was inferior to her sister.

But Huiyin didn't see it that way. She toasted with Li Cheng and enjoyed the performances. Especially after the emperor left, everyone in the hall became more relaxed. People kept coming to toast Li Cheng. Among them was He Guoguo. Huiyin saw them smiling and exchanging pleasantries, but beneath the smiles, there seemed to be something deeper. Huiyin didn't ask or look too closely, trying not to attract attention.

Her behavior was observed by Li Cheng, who admired her even more. He had never told her about certain military and state affairs, but Huiyin seemed to have an innate understanding of his thoughts.

"He Guoguo, I understand what you said," Li Cheng said with a smile.

"Then I will take my leave. I will invite you to my residence for a taste of Sanhua wine, a fine liquor, in the future," He Guoguo said, raising his cup.

Li Cheng courteously saw him off. The people around didn't pay much attention. Soon after, Li Heng reconnected with He Guoguo. "The Prince of Huaiyin agreed to persuade Zheng Fang to defect, but he has one condition: Qingzhou must be divided, with Zheng Fang taking half."

"He's trying to get a free ride," Li Heng was unwilling to agree.

Qingzhou was something he had worked hard to obtain, and there was no way he would hand it over.

He Guoguo smiled, "Naturally, the crown prince keeps his promises, but do you remember the story of Zhang Yi, the Qin state's prime minister, who tricked the Chu state into betraying the Qi state? To entice Chu into breaking its alliance with Qi, Zhang Yi offered to return the Shangyu region, a vast area of 600 li, to Chu. After Chu severed ties with Qi, they sent an envoy to Qin to demand the land, but Zhang Yi denied the promise. Furious, the King of Chu sent troops to attack Qin but lost three battles, leading to the decline of Chu's status as a major power.

For now, they could agree. After all, Qingzhou was controlled by both the He and Lü families. Once Lü Wei died, it would all belong to the He family. Whether to give any part to Li Cheng would be up to them.

In He Guoguo's eyes, his biggest threat right now was Lü Wei. Once Lü Wei was eliminated, he could swiftly deal with Zheng Fang. By then, the world would practically be his.

Hearing this, Li Heng also smiled, "Uncle is right. I will agree for now."

Even Li Heng had a strategy that could kill three birds with one stone. By using Qingzhou as a bargaining chip, he could make the He, Lü, and Li families fight among themselves, leaving him to be the balancing point.

It must be said that Li Heng was also a master at manipulating people's hearts. Just like now, De Yin had personally invited Huiyin to the Eastern Palace. De Yin spoke with a smile, "Dear sister, you've been back for a while but haven't come to visit me in the palace. I've been so worried about you."

Words like these, if coming from sisters who usually got along, would be sweet. But the relationship between De Yin and Huiyin had always been rather cold, so such words felt out of place.

However, Huiyin didn’t show any surprise. Instead, she smiled and said, "I was planning to come to the palace for the birthday celebration and didn’t want to trouble anyone. Besides, your Eastern Palace isn’t just any place. How could ordinary people casually enter?"

As soon as she finished speaking, Lianzhi brought over a cup of Jin Junmei tea. Huiyin picked it up and sniffed it, "Sister, your servant is quite clever to remember that I used to love Jin Junmei when I was at our parents' home."

Lianzhi bowed, "It's not that this servant remembered. It was Consort Liangdi who remembered."

"It was sister. I feel so awkward," Huiyin pretended to be at a loss for words.

De Yin was somewhat pleased. She had been learning social etiquette from elder Madame Xu since childhood. She knew which ladies preferred which teas, how to arrange seating for them, and how to quickly form friendships. These were mere trivial skills to her.

But she knew her sister wasn’t good at these things. Huiyin’s interactions with others were often cold and distant, making her unsuitable to be a mistress, and even basic interactions were difficult for her.

So, De Yin simply said, "You also love osmanthus cakes, steamed pork with rice flour, and chicken soup with peanuts. We are sisters. How could I not know these things? Since I moved into the inner palace, it’s been hard to see our family, and I’ve started missing the old days. Because of our families' influence, we sisters never really got to know each other. Thinking about it, I feel it was my fault as the elder sister."

"Sister, don’t say that. I’m already grateful that you, as Consort Liangdi of the Eastern Palace, still think of me," Huiyin couldn’t be moved by these few words.

De Yin was good at showing vulnerability. Seeing that Huiyin didn’t seem very emotional, she intensified her act with glistening tears, "I’m older than you and already married, yet you have a son, and I have nothing. Sometimes, I really envy you."

"Having a child is a matter of luck. Sister, you’re still young. What is there to worry about?" Huiyin prepared to leave. It was simple. De Yin suddenly calling her to the Eastern Palace during the birthday banquet probably also involved the Crown Prince’s plans.

After all, Li Heng’s so-called schemes were mostly used on women.

Sure enough, De Yin shifted her tone, "Alas, now I dare not have a child. In the Eastern Palace, there was a woman who became pregnant with the Crown Prince's child. Because she conceived before the Crown Princess, she was beaten to death by Prime Minister Lü."

Huiyin was shocked, "To such an extent—"

"Yes, so even if I were pregnant, I wouldn’t dare to keep it with Prime Minister Lü still around," De Yin’s voice was desolate.

But soon, she took a deep breath and continued, "The Crown Prince is also controlled enough. If Lü Wei continues to dominate the court, I’m afraid that my father, even my brother Wuheng, and I will be harmed in the future. You see, Dong Yuniang's elder brother was implicated."

"Father and Wuheng—" Huiyin showed a worried expression. She already understood why De Yin had called her. It was still about persuading Zheng Fang to eliminate Lü Wei. Probably, when He Guoguo approached Li Cheng, he was talking about the same thing.

He Guoguo didn’t ask Wei Duo for help because Wei Duo is too powerful, and once you bring him in, it’s hard to get rid of him. As for Zheng Fang, he was being used first. After all, Zheng Fang was brave but lacked strategy. He could kill Lü Wei because he was Lü Wei’s loyal follower, obeying Lü Wei’s commands and ruthlessly eliminating Lü Wei’s political enemies. Although Lü Wei was wary of Zheng Fang’s growing power, their relationship was complicated.

Zheng Fang was the only one who could command Lü Wei’s army.

In her previous life, she had her father help kill Lü Wei without hesitation, binding the Zheng family to the Crown Prince’s cause. Her elder brother lost his life, and her younger brother almost did too. But in this life, she couldn’t allow her father to be bound to anyone like that.

Li Cheng was not yet fully established. If her father killed Lü Wei, the He family, who had been eyeing Qingzhou for a long time, would eliminate him immediately. Jizhou was also a prime target.

How could she turn the tables? Regardless of whether Li Cheng agreed or not, everyone was looking out for themselves.

So, Huiyin looked at De Yin with raised eyebrows, "Sister, don’t put too much faith in the Crown Prince’s words. The Crown Prince is hedging his bets. Years ago, when the Crown Prince saved you from the water, he also saved me the next day. Even between us sisters, whoever marries him first will tie her family to the Crown Prince's cause. I originally didn’t want to say this, but now that you keep mentioning these matters, I have to bring it up."
